abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Nepticulidae represent one of the early diverging <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">L</jats:styled-content>epidoptera lineages, and the family currently comprises over 850 described species. The larvae of the vast majority of the species are leaf miners on <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ngiosperms and highly monophagous, which has led to persistent ideas on coevolution with their plant hosts. We present here a molecular phylogeny based on eight gene fragments from 355 species, representing 20 out of 22 extant <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>epticulidae genera. Using two fossil calibration points, we performed molecular dating to place the origin of the family in the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>arly <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>retaceous, before the main <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ngiosperm diversification. Based on our results we propose a new classification, abandoning all ranks between family and genus, as well as subgenera to allow for a stable classification. The position of <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>nteucha</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>eyrick within <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>epticulidae remains somewhat ambiguous, and the species‐rich cosmopolitan genus <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>tigmella</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>chrank, with nearly half of all described <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>epticulidae, requires further study. <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>ctoedemia</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>usck, <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">Z</jats:styled-content>immermannia</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ering, <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>calyptris</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>eyrick, <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>tainia</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>eirne, <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>arafomoria</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>orkowski, <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>uhabbetana</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">K</jats:styled-content>oçak & <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">K</jats:styled-content>emal and <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">F</jats:styled-content>omoria</jats:italic> <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>eirne appear to have diversified in a relatively short evolutionary period, leading to short branches in the molecular phylogeny and unclear suprageneric relations. Otherwise support values throughout the phylogeny are mostly high and the species groups, genera and higher clades are discussed in respect of their supporting morphological and life‐history characters. Wing venation characters are confirmed to be mostly reliable and relevant for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>epticulidae classification, but some other previously used characters require reinterpretation. The species groups of most genera are recovered, but only partly so in the large genus <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>tigmella</jats:italic>. The molecular dating results are compared with existing knowledge on the timing of the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ngiosperm radiation and reveal that the diversification of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">N</jats:styled-content>epticulidae could largely have been contemporaneous with their hosts, although some of the genera restricted to a single plant family appear to have begun to diversify before their hosts.</jats:p>
title: Phylogeny, classification and divergence times of pygmy leaf‐mining moths (<scp>L</scp>epidoptera: <scp>N</scp>epticulidae): the earliest lepidopteran radiation on <scp>A</scp>ngiosperms?
